TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit IcmpV6Statistics extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides Internet Control Message Protocol for Internet Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) statistical data for the local computer.

remarks.format:
## Remarks ICMPV6 is a set of error and informational messages for use with Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). This class is used by the <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalProperties.GetIcmpV6Statistics%2A> method to return ICMPV6 traffic information.
The properties in this class correlate to the Management Information Base objects for ICMPv6 defined in IETF RFC 2466. ICMPv6 is defined in RFC 2463.
## Examples The following example displays the current ICMPv6 statistics.
[!code-cpp[NCLNetInfoReport#7](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.net.networkinfo_1_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[NCLNetInfoReport#7](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.net.networkinfo_1_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This constructor can be called only by classes that derive from <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IcmpV6Statistics>.

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) messages received because of a packet having an unreachable address in its destination.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of Destination Unreachable messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A Destination Unreachable message can be sent to the computer that is the source of a packet for any of the following reasons:
- The computer cannot find a route to the destination address.
- Communication with the destination address is administratively prohibited. For example, a firewall prevents delivery of packets to the destination.
- The destination address is unreachable.
- The destination port is unreachable. For example, there is no listener available for the packet's protocol.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#32](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/430b1fd1-42ca-472e-a604-_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#32](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/430b1fd1-42ca-472e-a604-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#32](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/430b1fd1-42ca-472e-a604-_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) messages sent because of a packet having an unreachable address in its destination.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of Destination Unreachable messages sent.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A Destination Unreachable message can be sent to the computer that is the source of a packet for any of the following reasons:
- The computer cannot find a route to the destination address.
- Communication with the destination address is administratively prohibited. For example, a firewall prevents delivery of packets to the destination.
- The destination address is unreachable.
- The destination port is unreachable. For example, there is no listener available for the packet's protocol.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Echo Reply messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of number of ICMP Echo Reply messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Echo Request and Echo Reply messages allow a computer to request an ICMP response from a remote computer on a network. This functionality is often used to determine the validity of remote addresses.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#30](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_69_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#30](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_69_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#30](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_69_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Group management Protocol (IGMP) Group Membership Query messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of Group Membership Query messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Multicast routers send Group Membership Query messages to learn which groups have members on each of their attached physical networks. Host computers respond to a Group Membership Query message by sending a Group Membership Report for each multicast group joined by the host. A host computer can also send a Group Membership Report when it joins a new multicast group. Group Membership Reduction messages are sent when a host computer leaves a multicast group.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#34](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_15_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#34](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_15_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#34](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_15_1.cpp)]

remarks.format:

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Neighbor Advertisement messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Neighbor Advertisement messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Neighbor Discovery is a process whereby host computers and routers can determine the addresses for neighbors known to reside on shared links. Part of this discovery process is accomplished using ICMP messages called Neighbor Solicitations and Neighbor Advertisements. Neighbor Solicitation messages are sent to discover the link-layer address of a neighbor or to verify that a neighbor is still reachable via a cached link-layer address. A Neighbor Advertisement that contains address information is sent in response to a solicitation or to announce an address change.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#35](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_20_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#35](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_20_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#35](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_20_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Packet Too Big messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Packet Too Big messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A router sends a Packet Too Big message when a packet cannot be forwarded because it is larger than the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of the outgoing link.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#36](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_81_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#36](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_81_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#36](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_81_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Parameter Problem messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Parameter Problem messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Parameter Problem messages are sent when a host computer or router encounters problems while processing the contents of a packet header, such as encountering a invalid IPv6 option or a invalid Next Header type.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#39](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_110_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#39](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_110_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#39](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_110_1.cpp)]

Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Parameter Problem messages sent.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Parameter Problem messages are sent when a host computer or router encounters problems while processing the contents of a packet header, such as encountering an invalid IPv6 option or an invalid Next Header type.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Redirect messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Redirect messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Redirect messages are sent by routers to inform a host computer of a better route for a destination address.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#37](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_77_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#37](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_77_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#37](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_77_1.cpp)]

Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Redirect messages sent.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Redirect messages are sent by routers to inform a host computer of a better route for a destination address.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#37](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_78_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#37](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_78_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#37](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_78_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Router Advertisement messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of Router Advertisement messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Before a host computer can send IP datagrams beyond its directly attached subnet, it must discover the address of at least one router on that subnet. This discovery can be accomplished using ICMP messages called Router Advertisements and Router Solicitations. An Advertisement message is sent by a router periodically to announce its presence and the addresses of its interfaces. When a computer connects to a network, rather than waiting to receive Router Advertisements, it can send Router Solicitations to request that routers send their advertisements immediately.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#40](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_40_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#40](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_40_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#40](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_40_1.cpp)]

Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of Router Advertisement messages sent.

This discovery can be accomplished using ICMP messages called Router Advertisements and Router Solicitations. An Advertisement message is sent by a router periodically to announce its presence and the addresses of its interfaces. When a computer connects to a network, rather than waiting to receive Router Advertisements, it can send Router Solicitations to request that routers send their advertisements immediately.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Before a host computer can send IP datagrams beyond its directly attached subnet, it must discover the address of at least one router on that subnet. This discovery can be accomplished using ICMP messages called Router Advertisements and Router Solicitations. An Advertisement message is sent by a router periodically to announce its presence and the addresses of its interfaces. When a computer connects to a network, rather than waiting to receive Router Advertisements, it can send Router Solicitations to request that routers send their advertisements immediately.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#40](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_4_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#40](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_4_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#40](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_4_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Time Exceeded messages received.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Time Exceeded messages received.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A packet's Hop Limit determines how many times it can be forwarded before it is discarded. Each time a packet is forwarded, its Hop Limit value is decremented by one. When the Hop Limit reaches zero or when a router receives a packet with its Hop Limit set to zero, the packet is discarded and the source of the packet receives a Time Exceeded message indicating that the initial Hop Limit was too small or that the packet was caught in a routing loop.
## Examples The following example displays the value of this property.
[!code-cs[NCLNetInfo2#38](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.net.networkinfo_12_1.cs)] [!code-vb[NCLNetInfo2#38](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.net.networkinfo_12_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[NCLNetInfo2#38](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.net.networkinfo_12_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the number of Internet Control Message Protocol version 6 (ICMPv6) Time Exceeded messages sent.
Docs.value: An value that specifies the total number of ICMP Time Exceeded messages sent.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A packet's Hop Limit determines how many times it can be forwarded before it is discarded. Each time a packet is forwarded, its Hop Limit value is decremented by one. When the Hop Limit reaches zero or when a router receives a packet with its Hop Limit set to zero, the packet is discarded and the source of the packet receives a Time Exceeded message indicating that the initial Hop Limit was too small or that the packet was caught in a routing loop.
